conclusion: To determine which container the liquid from A, B, and C will flow into, we need to follow the path of the liquid through the system, taking into account the obstacles and the direction of flow.
Liquid from A is white/yellow, liquid from B is orange, and liquid from C is green.
Container D is orange, and container E is black.
The system contains various colored bars: cyan, orange, black, red, yellow, brown, and green.
The liquid from A flows downward and is initially blocked by the cyan bar.
The liquid from A then flows to the right, past the orange bar.
The liquid from A continues to the right around the black bar.
The liquid from A moves downward, bypassing the red bar.
The liquid from A finally flows into the orange container (D).
The liquid from B flows downward and is initially blocked by the black bar.
The liquid from B then flows to the right, past the red bar.
The liquid from B continues to the right, bypassing the yellow bar.
The liquid from B moves downward, bypassing the brown bar.
The liquid from B finally flows into the orange container (D).
The liquid from C flows downward and moves past the green bar.
The liquid from C then flows to the left, past the red bar.
The liquid from C continues to the left around the yellow bar.
The liquid from C moves downward, bypassing the brown bar.
The liquid from C finally flows into the black container (E).
The liquid from A and B will flow into container D (orange).
The liquid from C will flow into container E (black).
The liquid from A and B will flow into container D, and the liquid from C will flow into container E.
